Genres > Fantasy >

High Fantasy > New Releases

High fantasy is defined as fantasy fiction set in an alternative, entirely fictional ("secondary") world, rather than the real, or "primary" world. The secondary world is usually internally consistent but its rules differ in some way(s) from those of the primary world. By contrast, low fantasy is characterized by being set in the primary, or "real" world, or a rational and familiar fictional world, with the inclusion of magical elements.

Quotes Tagged “High Fantasy”

Therefore, I ask today that you reject Gaius Damora as your leader and take Prince Magnus as your new king. He will right the wrongs that have overtaken Mytica. And he will make Gaius Damora pay for all he has destroyed. ”
― Morgan Rhodes, Frozen Tides

“ Cold coiled through me, lacing each breath with clouded wisps of frost. There was not so much as a candle lit within the small, single room of my cottage, and delicate crystals of alabaster and beryl rimed my meagre possessions and the barren fireplace. I did not care. ”
― Hazel Butler, Bleizgeist

Indian Fantasy Aficionados
The group name could be Fantasy Aficionados from India. All genres of fantasy including but not…more
[close] The group name could be Fantasy Aficionados from India. All genres of fantasy including but not limited to: Comic fantasy, Contemporary fantasy, Dark fantasy, Dieselpunk, Fairy tale, Fairy tale parody, Fairytale fantasy, Fantastique, Fantasy literature, Fantasy of manners, Gaslamp fantasy, Ghost story, Gods and demons fiction, Gothic fiction, Hard fantasy, Heroic fantasy, High fantasy, Historical fantasy, Juvenile fantasy, Low fantasy, Magic realism, Medieval fantasy Mythic fiction, Mythopoeia, Paranormal romance, Romantic fantasy, Science fantasy,Steampunk, Superhero fiction,Supernatural fiction, Sword and sorcery, Time travel romance, Urban fantasy can be discussed here.

22 members, last active 2 years ago

Top Rated Books [fiction, adult, excluding roma...
Is anyone else tired of seeing Young Adult, Paranormal, Romance novels at the top of every list?…more
[close] Is anyone else tired of seeing Young Adult, Paranormal, Romance novels at the top of every list? The goal of this group is to root out, with your help, the highest rated books on goodreads. Thousands of books were consolidated from many different lists; unfortunately, not every book has been included in this analysis. Thus I create this group for help rooting out books that have been missed (or that have been erroneously excluded). I'm creating this as a Group instead of a List so that I can enable discussions/polls, and so that I can (somewhat) lock-down the bookshelves. To calculate the Top Rated Books, I have borrowed IMBDs Bayesian estimate formula to calculate a weighted rating. The use of Bayesian estimates ensures that a book with only a few hundred ratings, all at 5-stars, would not rank above "the Book Thief", for example, with a 4.37 average from over 500,000 ratings. The fewer ratings/votes a book has, the closer its weighted "bayesian" rating is to the mean rating of books queried, while the more votes/ratings a book gets, the closer its weighted "bayesian" rating gets to the pure average/mean for that individual book. EXCLUDED: books with less than 3,000 ratings books with a statistically weighted average less than 4-stars. non fiction (poetry/self-help) omnibus (box sets/complete works/short stories/collector's editions) romance (ya romance) childrens graphic novel prequel/sequel [only the first book in any series has been included] NOTE: The formula for calculating the Top Rated Books gives a true Bayesian estimate: weighted rating (WR) = (v ÷ (v+m)) × R + (m ÷ (v+m)) × C Where: R = average for the book (mean) = (Rating) v = number of votes for the book = (votes) m = minimum votes required to be listed in the Top Rated (currently 3000) C = the mean vote across the whole report (currently 3.5)

21 members, last active 2 months ago
